name: AJEnglish
text:
THREAD üëá

Life for children tasked with caring for sick or disabled relatives has become significantly tougher during the pandemic, as access to support services has dwindled or stopped altogether.

Meet some of these young front-line heroes https://t.co/7ZWgV3HPW3 https://t.co/34FihqpvtM

name: AJEnglish
text:
"I‚Äôd do anything for Johnny. But another lockdown would kill me ... I felt like I was suffocating."

In Australia, 19-year-old Rita, who is studying to be a social worker, has helped take care of her brother Johnny for as long as she can remember https://t.co/2DDLKPOqDy https://t.co/RppaNEoh2x

name: AJEnglish
text:
‚ÄúI miss school because normally it can be a chance to kind of not worry about Hunter ... But I will always look after Hunter, even when we‚Äôre grown up.‚Äù 

In Canada, 9-year-old Willow provides her 13-year-old brother Hunter with extensive emotional support https://t.co/2DDLKPOqDy https://t.co/uHEqnax7Z3

name: AJEnglish
text:
‚ÄúBeing a young carer genuinely does change you as a person ... I had to grow up earlier than my friends around me.‚Äù

18-year-old Samiha has been caring for her terminally ill mother for much of the past six years https://t.co/2DDLKPOqDy https://t.co/MvspuXUAnT

name: AJEnglish
text:
There is no data about the total number of young carers globally, but figures that do exist are mostly for Western countries & are stark: 
US - more than 1 million
UK - around 700,000
Australia - at least 235,000 

Read more on the lives of young carersüëá https://t.co/2DDLKPOqDy
